metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Economic Recovery Following the COVID-19 Pandemic: Resuming Elective Orthopaedic Surgery and Total Joint Arthroplasty Orthopaedic Economic Recovery Following the COVID-19 Pandemic: Resuming Elective Orthopaedic Surgery and Total Joint Arthroplasty

body_text.text: care beds. Other healthcare institutions are not under the same volume pressure, but have 25 financial issues due to the moratorium on elective surgical procedures. In an attempt to conserve 26 resources and slow the spread of disease the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services 27 (CMS) [9] , the Surgeon General, and The American College of Surgeons (ACS) [10] 28 recommended against elective surgeries. As the allocation of resources became more difficult, 35 29 states placed moratoriums on elective procedures [11] . The moratorium on elective procedures 30 jeopardizes the financial integrity of healthcare systems that are disproportionately reliant on 31 elective procedures as a revenue source. In response, the United States Congress passed the 32 Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES), a $2.2 trillion bill with $100 33 billion designated to hospitals and $350 billion designated to small businesses including private 34 orthopaedic practices [12] [13] [14] . Although these relief programs may alleviate some of the 35 economic burden, the legislation is not comprehensive, and it will not resolve all financial losses 36 accrued by healthcare systems and orthopaedic practices. Without the revenue from elective 37 procedures, many orthopaedic practices have had to furlough employees and withhold surgeon 38 salaries [15, 16] . Mayo Clinic has announced a projected $900 million shortfall, with employee 39 pay adjustments and furloughs [17] . 40 41 New York City has dealt with one third of the COVID-19 cases in the United States and has 42 become the epicenter of the US COVID-19 outbreak. However, the number of new 43 hospitalizations in New York has begun to decrease, giving hope that the peak of the pandemic is 44 near. As we reach this critical point, it is crucial that we begin to plan for a return to a more 45 normal healthcare reality. Healthcare and orthopaedic surgery will be an important component of 46 the economic recovery. The healthcare sector in America represents 18% of the United States 47

Gross Domestic Product (GDP) [18] . As orthopaedic surgeons we should help develop 48 sustainable institutional protocols allowing for the safe return of elective surgery and economic 49 profitability to healthcare institutions and orthopaedic practices. Total joint arthroplasty (TJA) 50 represents a large portion of orthopaedic revenue production due to high volume and high 51 margins. As we begin to make this transition, we need to understand that it will not be realistic 52 to conduct the same case volume as we were prior to the COVID-19 outbreak. We should assess 53 patient demand for elective TJA operations following the pandemic. Economic recovery will 54 require a safe and comprehensive approach for the sustainable resumption of elective 55 orthopaedic practice. We must also critically assess the economic impact of the COVID-19 crisis 56 so that we may adjust institutional protocols in a manner enabling an efficient response to future 57 pandemics. During the COVID-19 crisis, TJA has been deemed a non-essential procedure to help conserve 91 resources for COVID-19 patients. Loss of revenue from elective procedures for several months 92 of the fiscal year will guarantee that statements of operations for 2020 will record unfavorable 93 losses. Resuming TJA will be essential for economic recovery in healthcare. Lower extremity 94 TJA is one of the most effective, quality of life improving procedures available to patients [21] . 95

Resuming TJA will also be essential to improve the well-being of our patients, however, it must 96 be done in a safe and sustainable manner. Here we present Six Pillars required for the sustainable 97 resumption of elective TJA ( Figure 1 ). If properly implemented, we anticipate a return to a new 98 normal level of elective TJA by fiscal year 2021. 99 100 I.
In order to plan the orthopaedic economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, it will be 102 necessary to understand patient demand for elective TJA operations. Following the Great 103
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

body_text.text: Recession of 2008, demand for elective surgery was decreased because patients had to work, 104 they could not afford time to schedule hip and knee procedures, and many patients lost health 105 insurance. Following the COVID-19 crisis, patients will have the same economic, employment, 106 and insurance concerns, but patients may also be concerned about the risk of entering a 107 healthcare facility. It is likely that the demand surge we anticipate may be lower than expected. 108
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

body_text.text: Older patients may be reluctant to undergo procedures while the pandemic simmers and their risk 109 of infection is high. Younger patients may not be able to delay work for long periods of time to 110 recover or may have insurance issues. 111 112 It may be prudent for orthopaedic practices to assess patient demand by asking patients who 113
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

body_text.text: were cancelled for elective TJA operations if they want to reschedule immediately, cancel, or 114 wait 3 to 6 months. When orthopaedic practices understand demand for elective TJA services, 115 they can plan for efficient utilization of surgical facilities, which will be critical to economic 116 recovery and sustainability. 117 118 II.
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

body_text.text: Medical Optimization in a COVID-19 World with Evidence-Based Practices 119
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

body_text.text: As we begin to resume elective orthopaedic surgery cases, surgeons may be anxious to return to 120 the operating theatre. It will be imperative that orthopaedic surgeons adhere to evidence-based 121 medical optimization practices, which include local and federal recommendations regarding 122 testing elective TJA patients for COVID-19 exposure or immunity. TJA candidates with 123 substantial risk factors prior to surgery need to be optimized to ensure high-quality outcomes 124 Surgeons may be anxious to return to operating and will want block availability as soon as 132 possible. It is our recommendation that operating room availability be designated by division 133 instead of by surgeon, with urgent procedures prioritized. Hospital systems may want to consider 134 shifting elective orthopaedic surgery procedures to non-COVID or COVID-light facilities for 135 patient comfort, safety and peace of mind. Operating room staff will also need to be tested and 136 protected to provide a safe environment for the patients. 137 138 III.
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

body_text.text: Early Discharge and Outpatient Total Joint Arthroplasty 139
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

body_text.text: As orthopaedic surgeons restart their elective practices we anticipate an increase in early 140 discharge and outpatient TJA. The psychological barriers (e.g. pain and ambulation) preventing 141 eligible TJA candidates from considering early discharge and outpatient TJA will likely be less 142 relevant as patients attempt to distance themselves from exposure to COVID-19. It will be the 143 orthopaedic surgeon's responsibility to ensure that strict patient selection and screening be 144 performed prior to surgery at hospital outpatient departments (HOPD) and ambulatory surgery 145 centers (ASC). Patients not meeting the selection criteria for early discharge can instead be 146 enrolled in rapid recovery programs at a regional hospital with minimal COVID-19 exposure. 147
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

body_text.text: Adherence to strict patient selection protocols will allow high quality clinical outcomes, while The economic effects of the COVID-19 crisis are not like anything the United States healthcare 225 system has ever experienced. As we begin to emerge from the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic, 226 we need to plan the sustainable resumption of elective procedures. We must first ensure the 227 safety of our patients and surgical staff. It must be a priority to monitor the availability of 228 supplies for the continued care of patients suffering from COVID-19. As we resume elective 229 orthopaedic surgery and TJA, we must begin to reduce expenses by renegotiating vendor 230 contracts, use ASCs and HOPD's in a safe and effective manner, adhere to strict evidence-based 231 and COVID-19 adjusted practices, and incorporate telemedicine and other technology platforms 232 when feasible in order for healthcare systems and orthopaedic groups to survive economically. 233
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

body_text.text: The return to normalcy will be slow and may be different than what we are accustomed to, but 234 we must work together to plan a transition to a more sustainable healthcare reality which 235 accommodates a COVID-19 world. Our goal should be employing these lessons to achieve a 236 Table 1 . The projected 25% reduction in overhead costs can be achieved with the implementation of Pillar V, via the renegotiation for essential disposables (e.g. implants), office space, and imaging equipment, while temporarily eliminating non-essentials (e.g. robotics, navigation systems, custom implants, radiofrequency sealant devices).
body_text.section: Determine Patient Demand for Elective Orthopaedic Surgery Following the Pandemic 101

FIGREF0.text: COVID-19 Crisis of 2020 and The Great Recession of 2008 60 61 The immediate economic effects and fallout as a result of the COVID-19 crisis resemble that of 62 the Great Recession of 2008. A 2009 American Association of Hip and Knee Surgeons 63 (AAHKS) sponsored survey with 953 respondents evaluated the effects of the recession on 64 surgical and patient volume, practice type, hospital relationships, cost control mechanisms, 65 Medicare reimbursement, attitudes toward healthcare reform and retirement. The report found 66 that surgeons lost almost 30% of their retirement savings during the economic downturn of 2008, 67 surgeons planned to retire at an older age, and surgical and patient volume decreased by 30.4% 68 and 29.3%, respectively[19]. It is certain that in the short term, the COVID-19 crisis will have a 69 similar outcome as the Great Recession of 2008, temporarily slowing the demand for TJA. 70 71 The Great Recession further changed practice patterns as independent orthopaedic surgeons were 72 absorbed by large group-based practices or healthcare systems. The economic effects of COVID-73 19 may burden surgeons with debt caused by high overhead costs not offset by clinical revenue, 74 causing surgeons to seek more financially stable positions within large healthcare organizations. 75 Healthcare systems will further be impacted as the rate of patients with commercial insurance 76 coverage will decrease as the rate of unemployment increases. After the Great Recession, from 77 2009 to 2011, the decrease in inpatient admissions from patients with commercial insurance 78 resulted in an average loss of $3.7 million for a 300 bed hospital[20]. At the end of the COVID-79 19 crisis, unemployment is projected to be up to three times that of the Great Recession. The loss 80 of revenue due to the lack of commercial insurance after the COVID-19 crisis will far exceed 81 that felt during the Great Recession. A rapid reversal in the economy is possible, however, much 82 of this depends on how long state and federal restrictions are enforced, and how soon effective 83 testing is implemented[6]. Many financially troubled hospitals and healthcare systems may need 84 to be absorbed by financially healthier systems further decreasing patient, payor and surgeon 85 choice and thus narrowing the healthcare market further and continuing the consolidation which 86 began in 2008. 87 88 Resuming Elective Orthopaedic Practice: An Evolving Strategy from Surge to Sustainability 89 90

FIGREF1.text: orthopaedic practices to patients pertaining to any non-covered costs must 151 be complete, as patients may not have the financial capacity to cover these additional costs. For 152 Medicare patients, it will be necessary to identify any early discharge penalties that could create 153 an unneeded financial burden for the patient or practice[23]. Eliminating the increased out of 154 pocket expenditures for Medicare patients would be a helpful measure to assist in expediting the 155 safe care of our elderly, high risk patients. Extending HOPD and ASC hours of operation and 156 potentially operating on weekends presents another opportunity for orthopaedic practices to meet 157 the increased need for outpatient and early discharge TJA. Large private orthopaedic groups or 158 healthcare systems invested in HOPD and ASCs will profit from the increased case load, while 159 those who do not have access to ASC, HOPD or rapid recovery TJA programs may see be asked to consider eliminating the hospital-based reimbursement penalties 163 associated with the Two Midnight Rule. Hospitals should discharge patients as quickly as164 possible to avoid inpatient stays and should not face reimbursement penalties for efficiently 165 caring for the Medicare beneficiaries. Surgeons should be allowed to choose the appropriate 166 setting for their patients based on comorbidity burden to ensure that patients are cared for in the 167 right setting. Reimbursement should not be a consideration that slows down the discharge 168 process. It is time to evolve to a one 90-day payment each for Diagnosis Related Groups 469 169 and 470 to allow for the safest and most cost-effective care of TJA recipients. 170 171 IV. Technology and Innovation Investment 172 Perhaps one of the biggest benefits of the COVID-19 crisis has been the robust implementation 173 of telemedicine and virtual visits. Surgeon concerns about reimbursement, privacy and billing 174 has been partially resolved as a result of the pandemic. Orthopaedic surgeon practices in 175 Massachusetts have already begun evaluating the safety and effectiveness of virtual visits during 176 the 90-day global period[24]. During the COVID-19 crisis, it is not a requirement for practices to 177 use HIPPA compliant technology options, however, it is likely that in the future when 178 telemedicine is used for routine post-operative visits, the use of HIPPA compliant technology 179 will be necessary. The planning and implementation of telemedicine platforms will be expensive 180 and depends on a number of factors such as: education and training, number of providers and 181 patients, compatible devices and security costs and concerns. Traditional capital expenditure 182 purchase models for telemedicine platforms start at about $42,000, however, newer more 183 affordable options include per physician fees that start at around $799 per month [25]. It is 184 evident that the days of routine postoperative visits are fading and will be replaced with 185 telemedicine. Virtual visits provide the orthopaedic surgeon with an opportunity to increase 186 office efficacy and cost-effectiveness in an era of decreasing reimbursements and increasing time 187 constraints. New patient screening and long term post-operative surveillance of TJA patients are 188 also good applications for telemedicine and virtual visits. 189 190 Orthopaedic groups and healthcare systems should look to technology and innovation during this 191 transitional period to help sustain high-quality care in a cost-effective manner. It may also be a 192 time when consolidating staff means that both surgeons, physician extenders, technicians, and 193 nurses learn more skills to help each other distribute the workload as we return to the procedures are reinstated, we must become more cost conscious and re-examine the 198 major cost drivers. It is well-documented that implant cost is the main driver of inpatient costs 199 for TJA[26]. The renegotiation of contracts with vendors to decrease implant costs may help 200 reduce the expenses for TJA. The use of specialized hospital physician negotiating committees 201 may increase bargaining power and drive down costs [27]. Orthopaedic practices and healthcare 202 systems should also assess the possibility of renegotiating terms on office space and imaging 203 equipment (e.g. MRI, CT) with the aim of reducing overhead expenditures. Landlords and 204 bankers may be willing to write-off short term losses in the hope of retaining a long-term client. 205 Value added technologies which drive up TJA costs need to be reconsidered or renegotiated. 206 Robotics, navigation systems, custom implants, radiofrequency sealant devices, and other non-207 essential parts of arthroplasty care can be eliminated in this time of economic hardship in order 208 to minimize hospital cost. Reducing the fixed costs associated with TJA will improve financial 209 performance and mitigate the losses associated with the COVID-19 crisis as demonstrated practices are eligible for several funding programs through the United States 214 Small Business Administration (US-SBA) established by the CARES Act[14]. These programs 215were created to help small businesses with less than 500 employees navigate during the COVID-216 19 crisis. The loans, which can be as large as $10 million are guaranteed by the US-SBA and 217 may be eligible for forgiveness if used for payroll and employee retention. It is essential that 218 orthopaedic groups understand their financial options, enabling them to control overhead costs 219 while participating in government sponsored programs aimed at curbing the deleterious effects of 220 this crisis. Orthopaedic groups must continue to manage expenses and overhead to ensure that 221 they do not accumulate unsustainable debt.

FIGREF3.text: 6 economic pillars required for the successful implementation of sustainable elective orthopaedics. ASC: Ambulatory surgical center; HIPPA: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act; TJA: total joint arthroplasty; US-SBA: United States Small Business Administration Projected gross profit with adjusted and fixed overhead costs using assumptions presented in

TABREF0.text: while reducing resource expenditures[22]. Additionally, elective TJA candidates with non-125 modifiable risk factors who may need ICU beds or blood transfusions should be delayed if that 126 community has increased COVID-19 demand. Postoperative complications that lead to in 127 hospital readmission for TJA patients can lead to excessive resource utilization adversely 128 impacting the care of COVID-19 patients. Furthermore, the use and availability of medical 129 supplies must not be overlooked as we continue to care for COVID-19 patients. 130
